posts.title: How Alcohol Really Damages the Liver — The Role of Butyrate-Producing Gut Bacteria
posts.summary: Behind the common knowledge that "drinking harms the liver" lies the role of beneficial gut bacteria. Chronic alcohol consumption and Westernized diets reduce butyrate-producing bacteria, weaken the gut barrier, and ultimately drive liver inflammation.

posts.title: Collagen: How Much Do You Actually Need for Real Results?
posts.summary: Does low-molecular collagen really make a difference? Is 10g the right dose? We break down three key questions around collagen supplements using clinical evidence.

posts.title: What Is BCAA? The Amino Acid Story Behind Every Athlete's Gym Bag
posts.summary: BCAA (Branched-Chain Amino Acids) — leucine, isoleucine, and valine — are essential amino acids metabolized directly in muscles. Research reports reductions in muscle damage markers and fatigue, with benefits for both young athletes and elderly adults.

posts.title: Arginine: Can More Be Less?
posts.summary: The arginine market is booming with dosages soaring to 10,000mg. But bioavailability actually decreases at higher doses. We examine the most efficient absorption range and why formulation design matters more than raw dosage.

posts.title: Why Givaudan Paid $1.6B for Naturex
posts.summary: In 2018, Givaudan, the world's leading flavor and fragrance company, acquired Naturex — a French botanical extraction specialist — for approximately $1.6 billion. Behind this deal was the growing value of transparent, traceable ingredients.

posts.title: Fermentation-Derived Retinol: A New Wave in Cosmetic Ingredients
posts.summary: Retinol, the gold standard anti-aging ingredient, can now be produced through yeast fermentation instead of petroleum-based chemical synthesis. While the molecular structure remains identical regardless of production method, fermentation offers sustainability and vegan certification advantages.
